content.text: Chart Module
This workspace uses the Chart.js module at, available at the following URL:
https://www.apogeejs.com/modules/chartjsmodule/v2.0.0-p1/chartjsmodule.esm.js
This link should be added as a new
Web Module
under
References
in the left panel.
As seen from the url, we are using version 2.0 of the module.
Downloaded Data

Here we will download some data samples, from the years 1980, 2000 and 2017. (Unfortunately, these are the only years I have. The original location from which this data was obtained is no longer available.)
Population data by age and gender in 1980:
Population data by age and gender in 2000:
Population data by age and gender in 2017:
Processed Data

The chart cell allows different formats of data for input. Below we will use X values that are numeric. (Categories are also an option). For numeric X values there are three formats of data, which can be used depending on the format of your input data.
We will construct some of these alternate input formats here, to demonstrate the use of the chart.
X and Y Arrays
Here we want to construct arrays of our X and Y data.
Here we are constructing an array of XY points.
Charts
When components/cells are added through links in the references, they typically appear under
Additional Components
button in the toolbar. Find the entry for
Chart.js Cell
to add a Chart.js cell, as we have below.
Opening the
Input View
lets you enter the chart data.
We have done the following below:
We keep the default chart type:
line
when we create the chart. Other options are
bar
and
scatter
We selected
X Value type
as
Numeric
We added three data series, one for each of the three data formats allowed.
Format X and Y Arrays
These are simple arrays of X and Y data. We use the X and Y data arrays we constructed above.
Format XY Points
This is an array with each element having an "x" field and a "y" field.
Format Data Array and X And Y Accessors
This is the most flexible format. The data array is an arbitrary array of data. Along with it you provide accessor functions to read the X and Y values from a given element.
In the fields for the arrays and the accessors, you can type in javascript code. For example for the array you can enter the name of the variable or you can enter some other expression.
Check the input form to see the data added. Aside from the data input, a few additional options were also entered.
We can also construct a bar chart. The choice of chart type is given in the properties/create dialog.
Bar charts use category data instead of numeric data for X values. Below we are plugging in the same X array we used above, however.
The
X Category Array
is optional. If one is not included, a ones based array is used (which would be a bad choice in this case).
A scatter chart is also currently available. It is similar to a line chart except it does not show the line, only the points.
One More...
Here we plot by birth year rather than age.
The Generations
The names of these generations are well known. Their birth years are as follows:
Baby Boomers: 1946 - 1964
Millennials (Gen Y): 1981-1996
In the plots you can see the peaks for the Baby boomers and then for their kids, the millenials. Gen X and Gen Z are troughs in between.
It also looks like there was a peak around 1920 to 1930, which may correspond roughly to parents of the baby boomers.
Lastly, it looks like here is an anomaly in the data at 1900. I suspect that could be caused by a change in the century from 1800 to 1900 - a y1.9k issue?
